No I'm going off of John Locke.

I agree that you should be willing to compromise if you use public goods 
(i.e. roads). But in today's age it is irrelevant if you don't take any 
government assistance for your business. You are still forced to not 
discriminate. So why not take the benefits? Furthermore if the government 
gave people the option in exchanging their benefits for being allowed to 
operate independently and the business owner was in fact racist and did not 
allow blacks to eat at his place of business who would eat there? Very few 
people I would imagine. The place would go out of business anyway. You're 
imposing a cost on the business owner for his racism in multiple ways A) He 
is no longer getting any help from the gov't, B) He is choosing not to 
serve a large portion of potential customers, C) He is putting out negative 
opinion of his business to the general public. By not allowing this you are 
giving no punishment to the racist business owner, imposing no cost on him 
to not refuse to serve people he does not. He may very well decide to lower 
his quality of service instead and there would be nothing that the blacks 
could do about it other than not eat there entirely.

And going off of the SUPREME law of the land he does indeed have that 
right. The Constitution trumps all other law in this country last time I 
checked. You say I am trying to take the discussion to a position of 
irrelevancy but that is quite the contrary. What you are doing is looking 
at the very end of the string of laws and ideas that created the law that 
says a business owner may not discriminate. What I am doing is looking at 
the ideas that got us there and finding a contradiction in your opinion. 
You can sit there and think philosophy does not matter in the real world 
all you want but you're dead wrong.

comments.text:
+WeGotTehPie ...Holy Shit... you took the ideals of Ayn Rand (as presented 
satirically in Bioshock) straight to heart, didn't you?
Though, to an extent, I agree with you that a person's labor is his own 
entitlement, I also understand that we live in a society of compromise. In 
other words, if you want the benefits of the society in which you live you 
must be willing to agree to compromise. This brings us back to my original 
point: If you want to operate a public business (and agree to accept the 
benefits of said public business), then you must accept that the public 
(gay or "straight", smoking or non, etc.) will patronize your business. If, 
under the laws of the country in which you live, you decide to deny service 
to someone based upon an inconsequential thing (such as sexual preference) 
then you are subject to the same criticism you are presenting.
You can make a philosophical issue out of it all you want, and dilute the 
discussion all you want, but the basic point remains: If this *public 
business* owner wants to discriminate against peoples' who's lifestyle is 
in-congruent with  what his moldy old book of bronze-aged prophecy, he does 
not have that right in our society unless he declares his business a 
private establishment.
If it is a public business, it means it is open to *all* public, regardless 
of any social stigma. *Period*
*That* is the point. You can divert all you want, but that is still and 
always will be the point of not only this video, but this discussion.

comments.text:
+Nicholas Noviello No, I'm not from the US which also means I'm more likely 
to know at least something about 'Obamacare' than most people from the US 
are to know about almost anything outside of the US. The simple fact is 
that the affordable care act is a series of concessions on both sides that 
represents neither well, and reflects both in a poor light. It does nothing 
to address systemic issues in US healthcare that, in part, stem from the 
highly litigious nature of US society and the belief that any ill that 
befalls any individual is, somehow, someone else's responsibility. I have 
heard of some fat fucker suing McDonalds for some perceived loss of dignity 
because they couldn't get their fat arse in the seat. I would have thought 
the 'dignity' already undermined by the hulking fat arse. Another person 
sued because their hot drink burned them when they spilled it. I would have 
thought the hint was in the name 'hot drink'. Now McD's cups come advising 
you that your hot drink is, in fact, hot. Now this is not wholly off-topic. 
Much of the aggregiously expensive nature of US healthcare is due to 
insurance costs and litigation risks. people are not held accountable for 
their choices hence the type 2 diabetes epidemic which is nothing more than 
a series of 'lifestyle choices'. In New Zealand we have much better 
accessibility to healthcare through a public healthcare system. Litigation 
risk is functionally nil and the cost of healthcare as a % of GDP is lower 
than in the States. When we look at an issue such as this it is complicated 
by a suite of environmental factors but what I would say is that Obamacare 
is so much adulterated by concessions that it is a strawman. Equally, 
the 'right' would typically spend without limit on foreign military 
adventures and leave US healthcare in a parlous state. On the whole a very 
difficult issue that is not well-served by reduction to left and right.

of some of its constructs...of its failure to fulfill many of its 
extravagant promises...of the tolerance of the scientific community for 
unsubstantiated just-so stories, because we have a prior commitment...to 
materialism.

It is not that the methods and institutions of science somehow compel us to 
accept a material explanation of the phenomenal world, but...that we are 
forced by our a priori adherence to material causes to create an apparatus 
of investigation and a set of concepts that produce material explanations, 
no matter how counter-intuitive, no matter how mystifying to the 
uninitiated. Moreover, that materialism is an absolute, for we cannot allow 
a Divine Foot in the door."
